Late tipoff, but not the latest for U of L

Jonathan Lintner, jlintner@courier-journal.com 10:04 a.m. EST December 2, 2014

U of L's Terry Rozier, #0, dunks after picking off a pass intended for Cleveland State's Andre Yates, #1, during their game at the KFC Yum! Center. Nov. 26, 2014(Photo: Sam Upshaw Jr.; The C-J)

1 CONNECT 4 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

The University of Louisville and Ohio State basketball teams have John Belein’s sympathies.

It was just last week, after Michigan’s tip-off against Villanova was pushed back beyond 10 p.m., that the Wolverines’ coach went on an unprovoked tear about increasingly late games and ESPN’s role in them.

“I mean, I love ESPN, guys, I love it,” Beilein said, “but when they told me that the game was being moved back 15 minutes, something is wrong. We have a whole bunch of guys with 8:00 and 9:00 a.m. classes tomorrow morning and we move that game to 10:15 so that a football game could be finished.”

The root of Michigan’s delay was a Mid-American Football Conference game between Ohio and Miami (Ohio) that needed to finish on ESPN2.

U of L and Ohio State fans could run into a similar issue this evening, with Tuesday night’s tipoff scheduled for 9:35 p.m. at the KFC Yum! Center. But how often do 7:30 p.m. games between Syracuse and, ironically, Michigan go over their timeslots? If it’s close, that’s most of the time.

Cards-Buckeyes shouldn’t mark U of L’s latest tipoff time by any means. In the 2012 NCAA tournament, it started a round of 32 game against New Mexico State at 9:52 p.m. on the west coast.

So we’ll see what ESPN does with this one — and also if it ends before the calendar rolls over to Wednesday.

More from Beilin last week: “Let us start our game but this is way out of whack when we move a game 15 minutes. It’s already at the wrong time — 10 p.m. on the East Coast — and now move it more 15 minutes. I love ESPN — they’re so good for us — but they got that one wrong. We can’t do that to our student-athletes.Tell Spike Albrecht when he goes to his 9:00 class today that it was more important that we started that (at 10:15) than at 10:00. This is wrong, and we’re going to fix it.”

IN THE C-J

•Rick Pitino says he’s expecting the best atmosphere since the KFC Yum! Center opened for Tuesday night’s game. Of course, it’s up for debate what makes a good college basketball atmosphere. Columnist Tim Sullivan tackled the issue. (http://cjky.it/1rSwvSc)

•Late Monday night, the U of L football program announced that the injury to starting quarterback Reggie Bonnafon’s left leg wasn’t structural in nature and that the freshman out of Trinity could return for the Cardinals’ bowl game. (http://cjky.it/1AbF9ut)

•A 15.7 percent drop in wagering for Churchill Downs’ Fall Meet means that, including the Spring and September meets, all three saw double-digit dips this year. They coincide with the track increasing its takeout. (http://cjky.it/1vFLJJs)

AROUND THE WEB

•ESPN’s Jeff Goodman picked U of L to beat Ohio State by double digits this evening, writing Monday that “the key, though, is how the Buckeyes can contain Louisville big man Montrezl Harrell. I’m going with the Cards in this one, with ease.” (http://es.pn/1HSjD30)

•ACC blogger Andrea Adelson took up for the league in the wake of its 4-0 record Saturday against SEC teams, dispelling myths that, oh, it was against the weaker East Division. “The ACC is about to post a winning record against the SEC for the first time since 2003,” Adelson noted, “but the knee-jerk reaction is to continue to discredit the strides this league has made over the past two seasons.” (http://es.pn/11J2V56)

•Writing for TwinSpires.com, Kellie Reilly insists a victory on turf in last Saturday’s Grade I Hollywood Derby won’t clinch Horse of the Year or even champion 3-year-old male honors for California Chrome. “If we don't support Chrome, it doesn't mean we dislike him or are oblivious to his fans.,” she wrote. “…Some of us just don't think he was best on merit.” (http://bit.ly/1B9oBqd)

Jonathan Lintner can be reached at (502) 582-4199. Follow him on Twitter @JonathanLintner.
